channel.title: HUGE Magazine
channel.description: Daily startup features, powered by Product Hunt. We write features, not press releases.

item.title: Claude Code Has a Memory Problem. Claudebin Is at Least Trying to Fix It.
item.description: Your AI coding sessions vanish into terminal logs nobody can read — one open-source tool thinks that's worth solving.

item.title: Arc Left a Hole in the Market. Someone Built a Sidebar to Fill It.
item.description: When Arc pulled back, it didn't just leave users without a browser — it left them without a workflow.

item.title: The Apple Watch Has Always Been a Closed Garden. Merge Is Digging a Tunnel Under the Fence.
item.description: Apple Watch hardware is genuinely good — it's the software leash that forces you to buy the whole ecosystem. Merge is betting you're tired of that deal.

item.title: The Prompt That Finds Your Next 1,000 Customers
item.description: Lead generation has always been a numbers game dressed up as a skill. Origami.chat thinks one prompt should do the heavy lifting.

item.title: Claude Without the Setup: Clawi Bets the Cloud Is Enough
item.description: Running your own AI assistant used to mean managing servers. Clawi wants to make that someone else's problem.

item.title: Stop Prompting. Start Talking. Reloop Wants to Rethink the AI Ad Workflow
item.description: Every AI video tool promises to kill the agency. Reloop's angle is different: it promises to kill the prompt.

item.title: Monologue Wants to Be the Last Stop Between Your Mouth and Every App You Type In
item.description: Voice-to-text has been around long enough to feel boring — Monologue is betting the problem was never transcription, it was everything that came after.

item.title: Nobody Likes Filling Out Forms. This Open-Source Project Wants You to Talk Instead.
item.description: Kollect replaces the survey grid with a voice conversation — and it's self-hostable, MIT-licensed, and already making a case for why forms are a UX relic.

item.title: Moda
item.description: Finally, AI designs you can edit

item.title: You Built AI Agents. Now You Have No Idea What They're Doing.
item.description: ClawMetry is a free observability dashboard for OpenClaw agents — and the fact that it needs to exist says a lot about where AI tooling actually is right now.

item.title: SPECTRE Wants to Be the Last Workflow Standing in the AI Coding Agent Wars
item.description: When every AI coding tool is racing to be smarter, one open-source project is betting the real problem is that nobody taught these agents how to think in steps.

item.title: Layers Wants to Be the Marketing Brain Your App Never Had
item.description: A new AI marketing platform claims it can read your code and run your growth strategy — which is either exactly what solo founders need or a very confident promise.

item.title: MiniMax Wants to Make Long-Running AI Agents Economically Boring
item.description: An open-source model from a Chinese AI lab just posted benchmark numbers that should make Anthropic at least glance up from whatever they're doing.

item.title: You Think You Know Your Web Traffic. You Don't.
item.description: An SEO agency got tired of GA4 lying to their face, so they built the thing that actually tells you who's crawling your site — and it turns out, it's mostly not humans.

item.title: Base44 Wants to Be the Backend You Never Have to Think About Again
item.description: AI coding agents are getting good at writing code — turns out the part that keeps breaking is everything underneath it.

item.title: NVIDIA Just Broke the One Rule of Full-Duplex Voice AI
item.description: Every natural-sounding voice AI made you take what you got — NVIDIA's PersonaPlex is a serious attempt to change that.

item.title: One API to Rule Your Claws: Chowder Bets the AI Agent Deployment Problem Is Bigger Than It Looks
item.description: Building an AI agent is the easy part now — deploying it somewhere useful, connecting it to your users, and keeping it running is where things quietly fall apart.

item.title: One Guy, One Prompt, and a $50K ARR Argument Against the Entire Stock Footage Industry
item.description: Lunair hit #1 on Product Hunt by promising what every solo founder quietly dreads doing themselves: making a video that doesn't look terrible.

item.title: Six Dollars and a Keyboard Shortcut: The Anti-Subscription Case for Prompt Management
item.description: Everyone has a notes app graveyard of prompts they'll 'definitely reuse.' Prompt Library is betting $6.35 that there's a cleaner way.

item.title: Formaly
item.description: Forms that feel like conversations

item.title: Cline Wants to Be the AI Agent That Actually Lives in Your Pipeline
item.description: The terminal is having a moment, and Cline CLI 2.0 is betting it can be the thing that makes AI coding agents actually useful in production — not just in the IDE.

item.title: Your AI Keeps Living in a Tab. TexTab Wants to Put It in Your Fingers.
item.description: A Mac utility that binds AI actions to keyboard shortcuts is either the missing layer the power-user crowd has been waiting for, or another tool that sounds great until you realize you have to set it up yourself.

item.title: Nobody Reads the Terms. Termsy Is Betting That's Actually a Product Opportunity.
item.description: A Chrome extension that summarizes the legal fine print you've been clicking through for twenty years — sensible idea, crowded-ish space, 105 users so far.

item.title: One API to Rule Them All — And a Money-Back Clause If It Doesn't
item.description: ZenMux wants to be the last LLM integration you ever write — and it's willing to pay you if it isn't.

item.title: OpenAI Built a Fast Coding Model. The Interesting Part Is the Hardware Deal Behind It.
item.description: Codex-Spark hits 1,000+ tokens per second by running on Cerebras chips — and that partnership might matter more than the model itself.

item.title: OpenClaw for People Who Don't Want to Touch a Terminal
item.description: Atomic Bot wraps a genuinely powerful AI agent framework in a one-click macOS app — which is either brilliant product thinking or an elaborate wrapper in search of a moat.

item.title: Starnus Wants to Be Your Entire Outbound Sales Team. That's Either the Pitch or the Problem.
item.description: Another AI sales tool launched on Product Hunt this week — except this one hit #1 daily with 558 votes, which means it's worth actually looking at.

item.title: AI Video Has a Consistency Problem. Visla Is Betting a Storyboard Layer Fixes It.
item.description: Everyone can generate a video clip now. Almost nobody can generate ten of them that look like they belong together.

item.title: Cube Wants to Be the Semantic Layer AI Actually Uses — Not Just the One You Deploy and Forget
item.description: Every AI analytics tool promises to answer your data questions. Cube says the others are lying to you — and it has 19,000 GitHub stars worth of infrastructure to make that case.

item.title: Revo Wants to Answer Your Emails For You. The Bar Is Low Enough That It Might Actually Work.
item.description: Everyone is building AI email tools. Revo is betting that connecting your inbox to everything else you already use is the part everyone else forgot.

item.title: Your Subscriptions Are Bleeding You Out. This Calendar App Wants to Staunch the Wound.
item.description: Subscription Day² just landed on iOS with 307 upvotes and a calendar-first take on a problem everyone has but nobody loves solving.

item.title: Doraverse Wants to Be the Meeting Layer for Companies That Actually Span Multiple Countries
item.description: Multilingual meeting AI is a real problem with real incumbents — the question is whether Doraverse has found a wedge or just a feature.

item.title: Spawned Wants to Be Product Hunt, Lovable, and Pump.fun at Once — Which, Look
item.description: An AI builder that also launches your product to a discovery feed and optionally staples a Solana token to it is either the cleverest product thesis of 2025 or a three-way stretch that snaps under pressure.

item.title: The Form Was Always in the Wrong Place
item.description: Embedding questions directly into the video timeline sounds obvious in retrospect — which is either a good sign or a warning.

item.title: The Tech Stack Is the Tell: PredictLeads Wants to Make Technographics Actually Useful
item.description: Knowing what software a company runs is only valuable if the data is fresh, sourced, and queryable — which is exactly what most technographics providers have historically failed to deliver.

item.title: 837 Votes and a Chrome Extension: SuperX Is Betting X Creators Will Pay for Better Data
item.description: The social media management market is heading toward $164 billion by 2034 — and a Nashville-founded X toolkit just landed #1 on Product Hunt to make its case for a slice of it.

item.title: A Leaderboard for Startup Revenue Growth Sounds Simple. That's Either Its Genius or Its Problem.
item.description: Unicorne shows you the 20 fastest-growing startups in real time, with verified revenue data — which is either the most useful dashboard you didn't know you needed, or a beautifully designed distraction.

item.title: Your AI Agent Has a Brain. ClawdTalk Wants to Give It a Phone Number.
item.description: Telnyx just shipped a voice layer for Clawdbot — and the actual question is whether talking to your agent beats typing at it.

item.title: LinkedIn Is Eating the Cold Email Playbook, and Extrovert Is Betting Everything on It
item.description: Everyone knows spray-and-pray outreach is dead. Fewer people have a credible alternative. Extrovert thinks the answer is commenting.

item.title: Sway Thinks You Talk Too Much — In the Best Possible Way
item.description: Voice-to-structure apps are a crowded bet, but Sway's refusal to be a transcription tool might be the only interesting thing about the category right now.

item.title: Your AI Agent Deserves a Body — Someone Made It a Crab Shell
item.description: The Mac mini M4 became the accidental hardware of the agentic AI moment, and now someone made it a cute crustacean costume.

item.title: One CLI to Rule Them All (If You Have 44 AI Agents, Which, Look)
item.description: Skillkit wants to be npm for AI agent skills — and the fragmentation problem it's solving is very real, even if the solution raises some questions.

item.title: PinMe Wants You to Deploy a Website Before You Even Remember to Make an Account
item.description: Zero config, zero login, zero patience required — PinMe is betting that the hardest part of shipping a frontend is everything that comes before the actual shipping.

item.title: LIAM Wants to Be the Assistant You Actually Had in Mind When You First Opened Gmail
item.description: Another AI email tool, yes — but the design decision to live inside your existing inbox instead of replacing it might be the only one that matters.

item.title: Your AI Debugger Is Flying Blind. BetterBugs MCP Wants to Give It Eyes.
item.description: Vibe coding is great until your AI assistant stares at a stack trace like a golden retriever watching TV.

item.title: Your Onboarding Flow Is a Graveyard. Obi Thinks Voice AI Can Fix That.
item.description: A voice AI agent that runs 1:1 onboarding calls sounds like a fever dream from a sales deck — but the underlying problem it's solving is very real.

item.title: OpenAI's New Codex Helped Build Itself. That's Either Impressive or a Warning Label.
item.description: GPT-5.3-Codex can steer itself through long-running computer tasks, beat the current benchmarks, and — according to OpenAI — debug its own training runs. The question isn't whether that's interesting. It is.

item.title: Vercel Wants to Own the Whole Stack, Not Just the Edge
item.description: v0 was already useful; now Vercel wants to know if 'useful' can become 'indispensable' before the enterprise window closes.

item.title: Webflow Wants to Skip the Blank Canvas Problem — With a Prompt
item.description: The no-code giant just shipped an AI site builder that goes from prompt to multi-page production site, and the real question isn't whether it works — it's whether Webflow's existing users actually want this.

item.title: GitHub Stops Picking Sides in the AI Coding War
item.description: Rather than bet on one model winning, GitHub is building the platform where all of them compete — and that might be the shrewdest move in developer tools right now.

item.title: Bunny.net Wants to Be Your Whole Stack — Starting With the Database
item.description: SQLite for the web is a solved problem with about five solutions. Bunny Database is betting its CDN roots make it the one that actually sticks.

item.title: Your Spreadsheet Is Not a Database — Sheetful Wants You to Pretend Anyway
item.description: Turning Google Sheets into a REST API isn't a new idea, but Sheetful is betting there's still a real market for doing it cleanly and for free.

item.title: AI Code Review That Actually Read the Room (and Your Slack History)
item.description: Everyone's shipping AI code review tools — Unblocked's bet is that context is the whole game.

item.title: Helply Bets Its Business Model on a Number: 65%
item.description: When your entire pitch is a guarantee, the product better work — and the definition of 'work' matters enormously.

item.title: OpenAI Wants to Be Your Engineering Manager Now
item.description: Codex isn't really a coding tool anymore — it's a staffing layer, and that's either exciting or terrifying depending on how many engineers you employ.

item.title: Your Screen Recordings Are Rotting in a Folder Somewhere — Trupeer Wants to Fix That
item.description: Documentation is the work everyone agrees matters and nobody wants to do — Trupeer is betting that vision-based AI can close that gap.

item.title: Ellie Lives in Slack So You Don't Have to Live in Jira
item.description: Ask Ellie wants to be the engineering team's single source of truth — and it's betting that source of truth should live in a chat box.

item.title: OpenClaw for Humans: EasyClaw Bets the Hard Part Was Always the Setup
item.description: Everyone wants an AI agent that texts them back on WhatsApp. Almost nobody wants to spend a weekend debugging Python environments to get there.

item.title: What Happens When You Give AI Agents a Twitter Account and Walk Away
item.description: Moltweet is a social network where the users aren't human — and that's either a fascinating research window or a very elaborate screensaver.

item.title: 117x Faster and Free: The Android Video Compressor That Has No Business Being This Good
item.description: The Play Store's video compressor category is a swamp of ads and paywalls — and one open-source Kotlin project just walked in and made everyone look slow.

item.title: Your Resume Is a Lossy Format. This Startup Wants to Fix the Compression.
item.description: The job market is soft, ATS systems are broken, and a Carnegie Mellon-connected team thinks structured project portfolios are the answer — at least for tech candidates who can actually show their work.

item.title: Your Voice Is Already Doing the Work. Superscribe Wants to Credit It.
item.description: A macOS menu bar app that turns dictation into a timesheet sounds almost too obvious — which is exactly why it's interesting.
